title-group.article-title: Numerical simulation and analysis of fluid flow in double melt-blown die

article-meta.aff: 1National Engineering Laboratory for Modern Silk, Soochow University, Suzhou, People’s Republic of China
2College of Textiles, Donghua University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Kai Meng, National Engineering Laboratory for Modern Silk, Soochow University, Suzhou 215123, People’s Republic of China. Email: mk2009@suda.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Melt-blown die usually consists of two components: the coat-hanger feed distributor and the spinneret plate with a series of orifices. In this paper, fluid flow in double melt-blown die was simulated using the three-dimensional finite element method. The fluid flow inside the melt-blown die was analyzed, particularly the flow near the joint point of the double melt-blown die and the entrance of the orifice. Velocity distribution at the outlet of the die was also analyzed through a comparison with the fluid flow in the double melt-blown coat-hanger feed distributor. The results show that the convergence flow around the entrance of the orifice can improve the velocity distribution at the die’s outlet to a certain extent. The improved uniformity of the velocity distribution at the outlet of the double melt-blown die proves the feasibility of using side-by-side melt-blown die to fabricate wider uniform melt-blown webs.

body.p: Melt-blowing is a process in which high-velocity hot air blows a molten polymer extruded from a melt-blown die onto a conveyor or take-up screen to form a nonwoven web or fabric. In general, the fibers in the nonwoven web have diameters in the typical range of 2–7 µm,1 but nanofibers can also be seen in some cases.2 Nonwoven fabrics with ultrafine fibrous structure are used in a variety of commercial applications, such as filtration, insulation, and as sorbent material, among others.

There has been an ongoing effort to improve the uniformity of melt-blown nonwoven webs. Some researchers have focused on the physical mechanisms in the melt-blowing process,3,4 whereas others have paid attention to the mathematical model and flow field.5–9 However, melt-blown die also plays an important role in the uniformity of melt-blown nonwoven webs. Melt-blown die generally consists of two components: the coat-hanger feed distributor and the spinneret plate. In the melt-blowing process, polymer melt is first distributed across the die width by the coat-hanger feed distributor and then passed through the spinneret plate with a series of orifices. Next, the polymer melt is extruded from these orifices to form filament strands which are subsequently attenuated by hot air to form fine fibers. The uniformity of volumetric flow rate distribution at the outlets of these orifices has a direct relation to the nonwoven web uniformity.

Fluid flow in the coat-hanger feed distributor has been simulated using all kinds of numerical methods.10–12 The optimal design methods have also been created to achieve even polymer melt distribution across the web width.13–15 In our previous paper, a method based on the combination of evolution strategy and numerical simulation was presented to optimize the coat-hanger feed distributor.16 However, the previous studies regarded the coat-hanger feed distributor as a sheeting die and did not take the spinneret plate into consideration. Therefore, the effects of the spinneret plate on polymer distribution have not been discussed. In addition, despite many years of effort by various researchers, the fabrication of uniform wider nonwoven webs can be especially difficult. Some patents have shown the use of a plurality of side-by-side coat-hanger feed distributors that could ensure better web uniformity compared with the use of a single wider die.17–19 However, there have been limited theoretical studies on double or multiple melt-blown dies.

In this paper, fluid flow in the double melt-blown die and the effects of the spinneret plate on the velocity distribution are analyzed based on three-dimensional finite-element simulation. The feasibility of using plurality of side-by-side coat-hanger feed distributors to fabricate uniform wider nonwoven webs is also discussed.

sec.title: Double melt-blown die
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 1, the double melt-blown die is composed of two single coat-hanger distributors and one spinneret plate with a series of orifices. The two coat-hanger feed distributors are arranged side-by-side and share a common spinneret plate. There is no wall at the joint of the two distributors. The double melt-blown die is a whole body. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of the double melt-blown die.

Figure 2 shows the single coat-hanger feed distributor used in this paper, in which the radius of the inlet is 3 mm, the land height B is 2 mm, the half die width L is 24 mm, and the slot gap H is 1 mm. According to the one-dimensional analytical design method, the curve equation of the manifold can be described by (1)y(x)=y0((L-y)/L)n0 (2)R(x)=R0((L-y)/L)1/3 where y0 represents the value of y at x = 0, n0 represents the equation exponent, R represents the radius of the manifold, and R0 represents the value of R at x = 0. The values of y0, n0, and R0 are 6.0071, 0.3991, 3 mm, respectively.20 Figure 2.
Schematic diagram of the coat-hanger feed distributor.

Figure 3 shows the geometry of the orifice in the side view of the spinneret plate used in this paper, in which the length of the orifice w is 4 mm, the diameter of the orifice d is 0.4 mm, and the contraction angle θ is 50°. A spinneret plate in a melt-blowing process usually has 25 to 30 orifices per inch. In this paper, there are 116 orifices distributed evenly along the entire double melt-blown die width. Thus, the geometric model of the double melt-blown die can be determined according to the above value. Figure 3.
Side view of the spinneret plate.

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p: Assume that the fluid flow in the double melt-blown die is incompressible and isothermal. The non-Newtonian behavior of the fluid is considered by the pure viscous model, which is one of the most widely used principles in polymer rheology. Based on the above assumptions, the governing equations of the fluid flow are described as follows: (3)∇·V=0 (4)ρV·∇V=-∇P+∇·τ+ρg (5)τ=ηαγ (6)ηα=η0(1+(λγ)2)(n-1)/2 where V is the velocity vector, P is the pressure, τ is the stress tensor, ρ is the density, g is the acceleration gravity, ∇ is the gradient operator, γ is the rate-of-strain tensor, ηα is the apparent viscosity, η0 is the viscosity at shear rates approaching zero, λ is a relaxation time, and n is the power index. Molten polypropylene (PP) is used in this simulation. The material parameters ρ, η0, λ, and n are equal to 926 kg/m3, 2500 Pa·sn, 0.4 s, and 0.41, respectively, at the temperature of 240°C.

Equation (3) is the mass conservation equation with incompressible constraint and Equation (4) is the momentum balance equation.21 Equation (5) is the constitutive equation, in which the viscosity function is described using the Bird–Carreau law model of Equation (6).12

sec.title: Grid generation
sec.p:
Owing to the size difference between the fine orifices and other parts in the double melt-blown die, the entire geometric model was split into two parts when the grid was generated. Each part was meshed by different elements and node intervals. This grid generation technique can ensure computation accuracy without taking up too much computing time. Figure 4 shows the finite-element meshes of the double melt-blown die. Owing to the symmetrical feature on the x–y plane, only half of the die was meshed and simulated. As shown in Figure 4, the orifices were meshed using a wedge element with a node interval of 0.2 mm. The other part was meshed using a tetrahedral element with a node interval of 0.4 mm. The node interval was determined according to the geometric size and repeated simulation trials. Figure 4.
Finite-element meshes.

sec.title: Boundary conditions and solving
sec.p: A no-slip boundary condition was applied on the wall. At the symmetrical plane, the x-component velocity and surface tractions in both y and z directions were set to zero. The volumetric flow rate at the die inlet was 1 × 10−6 m3/s and a stationary and fully developed flow was assumed. At the die outlet, the normal force and tangential velocity were set to zero.
When the above conditions have been completed, the governing equations can be solved using commercial CFD software. The flow field in the double melt-blown die can then be visualized.

sec.title: Velocity field
sec.p:
Simulation results of fluid flow inside the double melt-blown die with the geometry specified above were obtained. The velocity vector distribution on symmetry plane is representative, as shown in Figure 5. The direction of arrows in Figure 5 represents the flow direction of the fluid. The length and color of the vector represent velocity magnitude. From Figure 5, the velocity magnitudes in the orifices are larger than those in other areas. Fluid flow inside the melt-blown die can be divided into two basic flow fields by the distinct velocity: one is the flow before the orifices and the other is that after the orifices. Sun and Zhang22 stated that polymer melt flow before the orifices fundamentally belongs to the shear flow and the flow after the orifices essentially belongs to the uniaxial extensional flow. The total pressure drop in the melt-blown die is the sum of pressure drop in the coat-hanger distributor and pressure drop through the orifices, which should be calculated by different equations for each kind of flow. This simulation result verified the theoretical analysis of Sun and Zhang. Figure 5.
Velocity vector distribution on the symmetry plane of the die.

For further analysis, the velocity vector distribution near the joint of the two coat-hanger feed distributor is magnified and shown in Figure 6. The figure shows that as the fluid approaches the entrance of the orifices, it starts to undergo a strong convergence flow and fluid velocity increases abruptly. The increasing kinetic energy is rooted in the pressure drop. The flow in the orifices is mainly attributed to the uniaxial extensional flow under the effect of the pressure drop, which exhibits more viscoelasticity. The flow before the orifices is fundamentally attributed to the shear flow. Therefore, the fluid should be treated as viscoelastic fluid instead of a pure viscous fluid when the entrance and exit effects of the orifices are discussed. Figure 6.
Magnified velocity vector distribution in the local area.

Figure 6 shows that the fluid flow near the joint of the two coat-hanger feed distributor is as regular as the other area. There are no circular and turbulent flows in this area, thereby proving that a plurality of coat-hanger feed distributors arranged side-by-side may be feasible in the fabrication of wider melt-blown webs. A detailed analysis is presented in the following section.

sec.title: Effects of spinneret plate
sec.p:
The uniformity of volumetric flow rate distribution at the outlet of the orifices has a direct relationship with web uniformity. Since the exit cross-section of every orifice is identical, the velocity distribution also represents the volumetric flow rate distribution. The relative velocity distribution at the outlet of the orifices versus the entire die width is plotted in Figure 7, where Va represents the average velocity, x = 0 represents the joint point in the double melt-blown die. The figure shows that velocity fluctuates above and below the mean velocity across the die width. Figure 7.
Velocity distribution at the outlet of the die.

For convenience of comparison, fluid flow in the double coat-hanger feed distributor was simulated under the same conditions as that of the simulation of double melt-blown die. Velocity distribution at the outlet of the double coat-hanger feed distributor is shown in Figure 8. The difference between Figures 7 and 8 is sensible. In Figure 8, the velocity distribution appears in a ‘wings shape’. It is easy to understand why the velocity at the two end points is lower according to the no-slip wall boundary condition. It is also easy to understand the ‘wings shape’ distribution because of the confluence of two streams at the joint point. Figure 8.
Velocity distribution at the outlet of the distributor.

The comparison between Figures 7 and 8 clearly shows the intuitive effects of the spinneret plate on the velocity distribution at the die outlet. The coat-hanger feed distributor is usually applied in a film or sheeting process, thus, the double coat-hanger feed distributor certainly affects the uniformity of the final product. However, in the melt-blowing process, the uniformity of the velocity distribution at the die outlet can be increased by the spinneret plate. In this paper, the coefficient of variation (CV) was used to evaluate the uniformity of the velocity distribution, which is defined as the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean value and is sometimes expressed as a percentage. If the CV is lower, the uniformity is better. The CVs of velocity distribution shown by Figures 7 and 8 are 0.5559% and 2.8365%, respectively. There is an apparent decrease in the CV when the spinneret plate is used.

The effects of the spinneret plate on velocity distribution can be explained by the convergence flow starting from the entrance of the orifices. Fluid entering into every orifice comes from the fluid around its entrance. Obviously, there is fluid mixing, which decreases the CV of velocity distribution at the die’s outlet. On the other hand, the fluctuation of velocity distribution is inevitable because the fluid velocity around every orifice entrance is different. Fluid flow in double melt-blown die with 96 orifices and 136 orifices was also simulated to support this explanation. The velocity distribution at the die’s outlet is similar to Figure 7. The CV of velocity distribution is 1.2514% and 1.2185%, respectively, proving that the fluid around every orifice differs with the change of the number of orifices across the same die width, leading to different velocity fluctuations and different CVs at the die’s outlet.

sec.title: Advantages of double melt-blown die
sec.p: The double melt-blown die has many advantages compared with the single die. First, as shown in the Figure 1, the height of the double melt-blown die is similar to that of the single melt-blown die but the die width is doubled. This feature may reduce the pressure drop from the die inlet to the die outlet, thereby lowering the energy consumption. Second, the flow path length and polymer residence time in the double melt-blown die are more consistent than those in the single die when the die width is the same. This feature can prevent uneven polymer distribution and degradation. Third, the double melt-blown die can reduce deformation under the conditions of high temperature and pressure compared with the single die.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this paper, fluid flow in double melt-blown die was simulated and analyzed. The conclusions are as follows.
Velocity distribution at the outlet of the double coat-hanger feed distributor becomes nonuniform because of the confluence of two streams from the joint point of two single coat-hanger feed distributors.
A spinneret plate with a series of orifices can improve the velocity distribution at the double melt-blown die’s outlet to a certain extent. The improvement can be attributed mainly to the convergence flow at the entrance of the orifice and can ensure uniformity of the velocity distribution at the die’s outlet as the die width enlarged.
Single melt-blown die can be arranged in a side-by-side relation to form a wider melt-blown die. This is a feasible method to fabricate uniform wider melt-blown webs.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant number 51106102).
